body.text1:
Si­murgh, al­so known as the king of birds, is de­scribed as a com­pos­ite crea­ture ‚Äî with a pea­cock tail, falcon body, a dog's head, li­on claws, and fish scales. These fea­tures sig­ni­fied her dom­i­nance over land, air, and wa­ter. She is thought to be gi­gan­tic, with the ca­pac­i­ty to car­ry an ele­phant or a whale. The sweep of her wings could dis­perse the clouds and cast a shad­ow so im­mense that it ri­valed the size of moun­tains.
In some ver­sions, Si­murgh is de­scribed with a hu­man head and fe­male breasts, and even in the other ver­sions, it is de­pic­ted as a fe­male bird with nest­lings. According to an ancient tale, Simurgh lives for 1700 years bursting into flames and is reborn ‚Äî like the Greek Phoenix. Her feathers are copper-colored, and it harbors a deep dislike for snakes, similar to the

body.text1:
Even af­ter Is­la­mi­za­tion, Si­murgh con­tin­ued to live in the arts, folk­tales, and lit­er­a­ture.
In Rudaki's rendition of Indian fables, Kalila va Dimna, Simurgh is portrayed as a benevolent king of birds. He is depicted as an image of honesty and kindness. One of the stories narrates how Simurgh rescues the chicks of a bird named Taitoo, who were seized by a river monster:
PodshƒÅh Simurgh, daryoro biburd,
Khonayo bacha bad-on Taitoo supurd...c

King Simurgh, on the sea's vast spree,
Returned the home and kids to Taitoo with glee.
In Fer­daw­si's ShƒÅh­nƒÅ­meh, Si­murgh is por­trayed as a guard­i­an and teach­er to Zol. Zol, born with al­bi­nism, was left in the Al­burz moun­tains by his fa­ther King SƒÅm, who con­sid­ered it a bad omen and de­mon­ic. Si­murgh finds him and God gives her mehr (love) and she takes him in, rais­es him and im­parts much of her wis­dom. When Zol grows up and wants to re­turn to his fa­ther, Si­murgh gives him three feath­ers. If he ev­er needs help, he can burn one to sum­mon her. Lat­er, Zol us­es one of the feath­ers dur­ing Rus­tam's birth, and Si­murgh de­liv­ers the child through a ce­sare­an. Then, she be­comes Rus­tam's guard­i­an, as­sist­ing him in his bat­tles.
